Theorems: Courant-Fisher Theorem: given a symmetric matrix A, eigenvalues $a_1 \geq ... \geq a_n$, $a_k = \max_{\dim(S)=k} \min_{x \in S} \frac{x^TAx}{x^Tx} = \min_{T \subseteq \mathbb{R}} \max_{x \in T} \frac{x^TAx}{x^Tx}$
Types of graphs: Dense graph: A graph where the number of edges is close to the maximal number of edges possible in the graph. $|E| = \theta(n^2)$
Sparse graph: A graph where the number of edges is close to the minimal number of edges possible. |E| = O(n)
Expander graph: For every set of vertices S with $S \leq \frac{n}{2}$, adding the set of neighbors of vertices in S to S will increase the size of the set by at least some c|S|.
Eigenvectors: For eigenvectors $v_1$, $v_2$, and eigenvalues $a_1$, $a_2$, $a_1 \neq a_2$, $v_1 \perp v_2$. This is assuming A is symmetric.
General Ideas: The eigenvalues of adjacency matrices reveal global graph properties not apparent from edge structure.
Laplacians: $L_{G \cup H} = L_G + L_H$ provided G and H share no edges.
Eigenvalues: If $\lambda_2$ > 0, then the graph is connected. The greater $\lambda_2$ is the denser the graph.
Lin Alg. Fundamentals: Rank: number of linearly independent columns in a matrix
Kernel/null space: The linear spaceof vectors that multiply with a matrix to equal 0.
rank + nullity = n for an mxn matrix
Self-adjoint: where T = T^*$ or $T = T^T$ (symmetric matrix). By definition T is self-adjoint if <Tv | w> = <v | Tw>.
For dot products: $<av_1 | v_2 > = a<v_1 | v_2>.$ For vectors $v_1, v_2 \in \mathbb{R}, <v_1 | av_2> = a<v_1 | v_2>$
Fourier Transforms: Fundamentally fourier transforms are a changing of basis of a function. Essentially rewriting a function f(x) as $f(1) * e_1 + f(2) * e_2 + ... f(n) * e_n$.
We use the Fourier Transform to change basis onto the eigenbasis of the Laplacian. If $L_G$ has eigenvectors $\{f_1, ..., f_n\}$, we can create an eigenbasis where $v_i = \sum c_i*f_i$

From there, we can then define arbitrary x as $x = \sum c_i * v_i$. By setting our eigenbasis that we create to be unitary, the eigenvector part of expressions will cancel out when dot producted against itself to make theorems simpler.
